hints.content: Start by understanding how to traverse a binary tree. You can use a breadth-first search (BFS) approach to explore the tree level by level. This will help you gather the sums of each level.
As you traverse the tree, maintain a list or an array to store the sum of values at each level. Remember to increment the level count as you move deeper into the tree.
Consider edge cases, such as when the tree has only one node or when all nodes are on the same level. How will your approach handle these scenarios?
Once you have the level sums, think about how you can sort or find the k-th largest sum efficiently. You might want to use a min-heap to keep track of the largest sums.
Remember to check if the number of levels is less than k. If so, you should return -1 as specified in the problem statement.
When calculating the level sums, ensure that you are correctly summing the values of all nodes at the current level before moving to the next one.
You can use a queue to facilitate the BFS traversal. At each level, enqueue the children of the nodes you are processing and calculate the sum for that level.
After collecting all the level sums, sort them in descending order. This will allow you to easily access the k-th largest sum.
If you're using a min-heap, you can insert each level sum into the heap and maintain its size to be at most k. The root of the heap will then represent the k-th largest sum.
Once you have the sorted list or heap, simply return the k-th largest sum. Remember to handle the case where k is greater than the number of levels.

questionNotes: If there are fewer than k levels in the tree, return -1.
Level sums are not necessarily distinct, so k-th largest can refer to repeated sums.
